claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 139:
When a period is provided for in hours, the period commences immediately at the specified time.



        Conclusion:
        If an agreement is made at 10:00 a.m. on June 3 of a given year that the obligation will be fulfilled within five hours,the period commences at 10:00 a.m. of the same day, which does not fall on Sunday, holiday as provided in the Act on National Holidays, or any other holiday..'''
argument: According to Article 139, when a period is provided in hours, it commences immediately at the specified time. Therefore, if an agreement is made at 10:00 a.m. on June 3 of a given year to fulfill an obligation within five hours, the period starts immediately at 10:00 a.m. of the same day, assuming the day does not fall on a Sunday, national holiday, or any other holiday as defined by the Act on National Holidays.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 102:
An act that a person with qualified legal capacity performs as an agent of another person may not be rescinded on the grounds of qualified legal capacity; provided, however, that this does not apply to an act performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.
(Authority of an Agent with No Specifically Defined Authority)



        Conclusion:
        A contract may not be rescinded by the principal after it is performed by an agent with a counterparty even if it turns out that the agent was a person with limited capacity..'''
argument: According to Article 102, an act performed by an agent on behalf of another person cannot be rescinded solely on the grounds of the agent's qualified legal capacity, unless the agent was also a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity. Therefore, if an agent with limited capacity enters into a contract on behalf of a principal, the principal cannot rescind the contract after it has been performed by the agent, as long as the agent was not also a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 9:
A juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable; provided, however, that this does not apply to the purchase of daily necessities or to any other act involved in day-to-day life.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Guardianship)



        Conclusion:
        The purchase of daily household items may not be rescinded, even if an adult ward performed the act..'''
argument: According to Article 9, any juridical act performed by an adult ward is generally voidable, except for the purchase of daily necessities or acts involved in day-to-day life. Therefore, if an adult ward purchases daily household items, this specific act falls under the exception and cannot be rescinded, making the conclusion valid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 243:
If two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. The same applies if excessive expense is required to separate the movables.



        Conclusion:
        If two or more movables with different owners are so joined to each other that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite Thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables..'''
argument: Article 243 explicitly states that if movable properties with different owners are joined in such a way that they cannot be separated without damage, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. This directly supports the conclusion that in cases where movables are joined and cannot be separated without damaging them, ownership of the composite thing should vest in the owner of the principal movables.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 192:
A person that commences the possession of movables peacefully and openly by a transactional act acquires the rights that are exercised with respect to the movables immediately if the person possesses it in good faith and without negligence.
(Recovery of Stolen or Lost Property)



        Conclusion:
        A took the jewelry that B had forgotten, believing without negligence that it belonged to A. In this case, A may not obtain the ownership of the jewelry by good faith acquisition..'''
argument: According to Article 192, good faith and the absence of negligence are necessary conditions for acquiring ownership through possession. In the case described, although A possesses the jewelry in good faith and without negligence, the jewelry originally belongs to B, who merely forgot it. Since B did not voluntarily transfer possession to A, the conditions for good faith acquisition as per Article 192 are not met, thus A cannot obtain ownership of the jewelry.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 356:
The pledgee of immovables may use and profit from the immovables that are the subject matter of a pledge in line with the way the relevant immovables are used.
(Management Expenses Borne by Pledgees of Immovables)



        Conclusion:
        In pledges of immovables, pledgees and a pledgors may conclude a special provision that the pledgees may not use and receive the profits from the immovable property that is the subject matter of the pledge..'''
argument: Article 356 establishes a general rule that pledgees of immovables can use and profit from the immovables they pledge, but the conclusion states that a special provision can be made where pledgees do not use or profit from the pledged immovables, which does not contradict Article 356 as it allows for exceptions or special agreements between the pledgee and pledgor.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 423-6:
If the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay.
(Obligee's Right of Subrogation to Preserve the Right to Request Registration)



        Conclusion:
        If the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay..'''
argument: Article 423-6 directly states that if the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, they must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay, which logically entails the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 3-2:
If the person making a juridical act did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the juridical act is void.
Section 3 Capacity to Act
(Age of Majority)



        Conclusion:
        If a party to a contract did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the nullity of the contract may be asserted even against a third party in good faith and acting without negligence..'''
argument: If a party to a contract lacks mental capacity when manifesting their intention, according to Article 3-2, the juridical act is void. Therefore, the contract is null and void due to the absence of mental capacity, which means that the nullity of the contract can be asserted even against a third party in good faith and acting without negligence.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 378:
If a third party that purchases the ownership or superficies of a mortgaged immovables pays the price of the same to a mortgagee at the request of the same mortgagee, that mortgage is terminated for the benefit of that third party.
(Claims for Extinguishment of Mortgages)



        Conclusion:
        A created a mortgage on Land X, owned by A, for the benefit of B and thereafter sold Land X to C. In this case, if C pays the price of the same to B at the request of B, the mortgage shall be terminated..'''
argument: According to Article 378, if a third party (in this case, C) purchases the ownership of a mortgaged immovable (Land X) and pays the price to the mortgagee (B) at the mortgagee's request, the mortgage is terminated for the benefit of that third party (C). Therefore, since C purchased Land X and paid the price to B at B's request, the mortgage originally created by A for B's benefit is terminated.
